markdownRemark.html:
We all have certain practices or things we like to do when using software tools. I realised that when it comes to git, I have a lot of personal habits that I use on a daily basis.

1. Use of the command line

First, I always, and I cannot stress that enough‚Ä¶ ALWAYS use git from the command line. Why, you may ask ? There are 2 main motivations for my case: productivity and control over what I am doing. I have seen lots of developpers use integrated tools like git clients or IDE integrated clients. The problem with that approach is that when somethings goes wrong for them, they often need help understanding what‚Äôs happening. I personnally favor the command line as you gain a lot of time on simple tasks (pulling/pushing to a repo) and helps you have a better understanding as a whole of the tool, especially more advanced commands.

If you are under Linux, you probably have it already installed as soon as you open your shell. If not, use your package manager

If you are working with Windows (yes we don‚Äôt always have the choice üòû), then one of these tools might come in handy:

  • Git Bash
  • Cmder
  • ConEmu

2. Use of aliases

Switching branches, showing the working tree status, committing. Repeating all these commands might be a little tedious. Aliases are the perfect solution to gain time ! For example, instead of writing git status, why not just write git st

Here are a number of aliases that are very practical:

git config --global alias.co checkout
git config --global alias.br branch
git config --global alias.ci commit
git config --global alias.st status
git config --global alias.last 'log -1 HEAD'

3. Reviewing changes / Patching

All too often, a developper has been working on a functionnality for a couple of hours and at the end of it, finds himself saying: ‚ÄúOkay this is ready, works for me, time to commit my changes‚Äù. If you have encountered that situation you realise what is the risk here. You are about to commit, believe you have tested your code and have been careful and meticulous of your craft, but in the end will commit something unwanted (e.g: a typo, a log, an unwanted file etc.).

Why does that happen ? Primarily because committing seems easy, and we think that the hardest part of the job is over. Also, you might have used one of those cursed commands git add --all or git add .

üí° The commands git add -A or git add --all are equivalent and will add all changes to the index. On the other hand, git add . will stage new files and modifications without deletions on the current directory.

‚ö†Ô∏èIf something unwanted is in your current changes, those 2 commands are likely to stage them for commit !

An elegant alternative to adding everything in your unstaged changes without reviewing them is to go through git‚Äôs beloved interactive mode.

The git add documentation explains how git add -p works

Interactively choose hunks of patch between the index and the work tree and add them to the index. This gives the user a chance to review the difference before adding modified contents to the index.

This means that we will get a chance to go through each of our changes and review them before staging them for our next commit.

For example, I made the following changes to my code. The first change, is intentional, so I approve it. However, I do not want to stage the second one, so I reject it.

When I run the git status command, I will then see which changes I have stages and which ones aren‚Äôt. Therefore, I have reviewed my changes and can safely proceed to commit.

We can can also apply patching to unstage files using git reset -p {filename}
